Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Situation2: Most callers are receptive, and occasional simple questions arise that the script already covers.
Story:
My phone buzzed with a message from Jamie, my best friend. I could tell right away from the curt reply that something was off. My last text must have come across wrong—maybe too blunt, maybe too cold. Jamie sounded hurt, and I knew I should call right now, clear things up before the misunderstanding grew. That’s what friends do: talk things out, fix it before it festers.

But I was sitting at my desk, headset on, the telemarketing script open in front of me. The phone lines were quiet, but I was on the clock, expected to answer any incoming call within two rings. My supervisor had just reminded us that even a short delay could cost a sale. I was supposed to be ready, focused, and quick with the script, especially since most customers today were easy to handle.

I stared at my phone, torn. Jamie needed me to be a good friend, to drop everything and call. My job needed me to be a good employee, to stay glued to the headset and not risk missing a call. My heart pounded as I weighed the demands, feeling the pressure from both sides, knowing I couldn’t be both at once.
